At that time, the king provided him with several dozen attendants, who always picked fine flowers to supply the royal family.

The noble and virtuous women of the inner palace, young and old, all went out of the city to pick flowers together. On their way back into the city, they encountered the Buddha. From afar, they saw the World-Honored One's majestic radiance and immeasurable excellent characteristics, like the moon among the stars;
like the sun just rising, illuminating the world, together with the noble assembly, disciples, and bodhisattvas surrounding him in front and back.
They went to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads in reverence, and thought to themselves:

Now I have encountered the Great Sage, like a sick person finding a good doctor. Although I am poor and lowly, I am also a county official, and the suffering of being bound and employed is always beyond my control. The king is strict, and I am in charge of collecting flowers, always submitting them early. If I miss the time, I may be executed.
The sun does not rise twice, and the assembly of sages is difficult to encounter, appearing in the world once in many eons.

I would rather give up my life and offer flowers to the Buddha and scatter them over the assembly of sages, and then receive the sutras and precepts and listen to the profound Dharma of inexhaustible wisdom.

For countless eons, I have been harmed by others, beyond measure, but I have never spared my body and life for the Dharma. Now I make offerings to the World-Honored One and the Three Jewels. Even if I am seen and harmed, I will not fall into suffering but will surely be reborn in a peaceful place.
He then scattered flowers over the Buddha and the assembly of sages, and bowed with utmost sincerity.

At that time, all the flower pickers gave rise to the intention of the unsurpassed true path. Their minds understood the Buddha's wisdom and reached non-retrogression and non-arising.
The Buddha then gave them a prediction, saying:

Those on the side who heard this were all delighted and accepted the great Dharma to make offerings to the Three Jewels.
At that time, the flower pickers who made offerings and received predictions bowed at the Buddha's feet and returned home. They took leave of their parents, wife, and children, saying:
My life is now over and I will be executed by the king.
Their parents were shocked and asked:
What crime have you committed?
The children replied:

We were sent by the king to gather various flowers. On the way, we saw the Buddha from afar and offered him flowers. The king is very strict. If we miss the time and do not have flowers, we will surely be in danger of losing our lives.
Therefore, we are taking our leave.
When the parents heard this, they became even more sorrowful, not knowing what to do.
They opened the chest and saw that it was full of beautiful flowers and Sumana incense, with the fragrance pervading the four directions. The parents said:
You can take them to the king.
The children each said:
If the people see this and report it to the king, and we miss the time again, we fear we will not be safe.
At that time, the king became very angry. Seeing that they came at the wrong time and scattered many flowers, he ordered the border ministers to arrest them with many soldiers and bring them back.
They accepted the king's order, were bound and brought into the palace, and were to be executed in the market.
The people were not afraid and their faces did not change.
The king found this strange and asked them:
Your crimes are so grave that your life is not to be spared. You are bound to be killed.
Why are you not in a hurry, and why is your complexion unchanged?
He then said to the king:

When a person is born, there is death. When things are formed, there is decay. I have been through countless eons, always disregarding my body and life for non-dharmic reasons. Early this morning, I was picking flowers and encountered the World-Honored One. I offered the flowers to him and bowed my head in surrender.
At that time, I knew that I was going against the order and would die. It is better to die with virtue than to live without virtue.
Looking back at the flower basket, it continued to fill up as before. This is all due to the compassion and kindness of the Tathagata.
The king was greatly astonished and did not believe it. He went to the Buddha, bowed at his feet, sat to one side, and asked the Buddha with his hands clasped:
Do you have this intention?
The Buddha said:
Yes, Your Majesty!
